com.mousebird.maply

Class MaplyBaseController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mousebird.maply.MaplyBaseController
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GlobeController, MapController

    public class MaplyBaseController
extends java.lang.Object
    The base controller is a base class for both Maply and WhirlyGlobe controllers.

    Most of the functionality is shared between the 2D and 3D maps and so it is implemented here.

      • frameInterval

        public int frameInterval
        This is how often we'll kick off a render when the frame sync comes in. We get a notification when the render for a given frame starts, this is usually 60 times a second. This tells us how many to skip to achieve our desired frame rate. 2 means 30hz. 3 means 20hz and so forth.

      • disposeAfterRemoval

        public boolean disposeAfterRemoval
        If set, we'll explicitly call dispose on any objects that were being kept around for selection.

    • Constructor Detail

      • MaplyBaseController

        public MaplyBaseController(android.app.Activity mainActivity,
                           MaplyBaseController.Settings settings)
        Construct the maply controller with an Activity. We need access to a few of the usual Android resources.

        On construction the Controller will create the scene, the view, kick off the OpenGL ES surface, and construct a layer thread for handling data requests.

        The controller also sets up some default gestures and handles those callbacks.

        Parameters:
        mainActivity - Your main activity that we'll attach ourselves to.

      • getActivity

        public android.app.Activity getActivity()
        Activity for the whole app.

      • getWorkingThread

        public LayerThread getWorkingThread()
        Returns a layer thread you can do whatever you like on. You don't have to be particularly fast about it, it won't hold up the main layer thread. These layer threads are set up with the proper OpenGL contexts so they're fast to add new geometry using the ThreadCurrent option.

      • usesTextureView

        public boolean usesTextureView()
        Returns true if we set up a TextureView rather than a SurfaceView.

      • makeLayerThread

        public LayerThread makeLayerThread(boolean handlesViewUpdates)
        Makes a new layer thread for toolkit related tasks.
        Parameters:
        handlesViewUpdates - If set, the layer thread will deal with view updates. If not set, it's a simpler layer thread.

        public void setViewExtents(Point2d ll,
                           Point2d ur)
        Set the viewport the user is allowed to move within. These are lat/lon coordinates in radians.
        Parameters:
        ll - Lower left corner.
        ur - Upper right corner.

      • screenPointFromGeoBatch

        public boolean screenPointFromGeoBatch(double[] inX,
                                       double[] inY,
                                       double[] inZ,
                                       double[] outX,
                                       double[] outY)
        Batch version of the screenPointFromGeo method. This version is here for users to convert a whole group of coordinates all at once. Doing it individually is just too slow in Java.
        Parameters:
        inX - Longitude in radians.
        inY - Latitude in radians.
        inZ - Z value. Set this to zero most of the time.
        outX - X point on screen. MAXFLOAT if this is behind the globe.
        outY - Y point on screen. MAXFLOAT if this is behind the globe.

      • geoPointFromScreenBatch

        public boolean geoPointFromScreenBatch(double[] inX,
                                       double[] inY,
                                       double[] outX,
                                       double[] outY)
        Batch version of the geoPointFromScreen method. This version is here for users to convert a whole group of coordinates all at once. Doing it individually is just too slow in Java.
        Parameters:
        inX -
        inY -
        outX -
        outY -

      • setPerfInterval

        public void setPerfInterval(int inPerfInterval)
        Report performance stats in the console ever few frames. Setting this to zero turns it off.
        Parameters:
        inPerfInterval -

      • heightForMapScale

        public double heightForMapScale(double scale)
        Calculate the height that corresponds to a given Mapnik-style map scale.
        Figure out the viewer height that corresponds to a given scale denominator (ala Mapnik). This height will probably be use for visibility ranges on geometry. This works as a mechanism for making geometry appear at certain map scales and disappear at others.
        Returns:
        Returns the height or 0.0 if the system isn't initialized yet.

      • currentMapZoom

        public double currentMapZoom(Point2d geoCoord)
        Return the current map zoom from the viewpoint.
        Calculate the map zoom (TMS) based on the current screen size and the 3D viewport.
        Parameters:
        geoCoord - the location to calculate for. This is needed because zoom is dependant on latitude.
        Returns:
        Returns the map zoom or 0.0 if the system is not yet initialized.

      • currentMapScale

        public double currentMapScale()
        Return the current scale denominator (Mapnik).
        See https://github.com/mapnik/mapnik/wiki/ScaleAndPpi for a definition of the Mapnik scale denominator.
        Returns:
        Returns the current scale denominator or 0.0 if the system is not yet initialized.

      • addVectors

        public ComponentObject addVectors(java.util.List<VectorObject> vecs,
                                  VectorInfo vecInfo,
                                  MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add vectors to the MaplyController to display. Vectors are linear or areal features with line width, filled style, color and so forth defined by the VectorInfo class.
        Parameters:
        vecs - A list of VectorObject's created by the user or read in from various sources.
        vecInfo - A description of how the vectors should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the vectors once created.

      • changeVectors

        public void changeVectors(ComponentObject vecObj,
                          VectorInfo vecInfo,
                          MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Change the visual representation of the given vectors.
        Parameters:
        vecObj - The component object returned by the original addVectors() call.
        vecInfo - Visual representation to use for the changes.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addWideVectors

        public ComponentObject addWideVectors(java.util.List<VectorObject> vecs,
                                      WideVectorInfo wideVecInfo,
                                      MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add wide vectors to the MaplyController to display. Vectors are linear or areal features with line width, filled style, color and so forth defined by the WideVectorInfo class.
        Wide vectors differ from regular lines in that they're implemented with a more complicated shader. They can be arbitrarily large, have textures, and have a transparent falloff at the edges. This makes them look anti-aliased.
        Parameters:
        vecs - A list of VectorObject's created by the user or read in from various sources.
        wideVecInfo - A description of how the vectors should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the vectors once created.

      • addWideVector

        public ComponentObject addWideVector(VectorObject vec,
                                     WideVectorInfo wideVecInfo,
                                     MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add wide vectors to the MaplyController to display. Vectors are linear or areal features with line width, filled style, color and so forth defined by the WideVectorInfo class.
        Wide vectors differ from regular lines in that they're implemented with a more complicated shader. They can be arbitrarily large, have textures, and have a transparent falloff at the edges. This makes them look anti-aliased.
        Parameters:
        vec - The vector object to turn into wide vectors.
        wideVecInfo - A description of how the vectors should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the vectors once created.

      • instanceWideVectors

        public ComponentObject instanceWideVectors(ComponentObject inCompObj,
                                           WideVectorInfo wideVecInfo,
                                           MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Instance an existing set of wide vectors but change their parameters.
        Wide vectors can take up a lot of memory. So if you want to display the same set with different parameters (e.g. width, color) this is the way to do it.
        Parameters:
        inCompObj - The Component Object returned by an addWideVectors call.
        wideVecInfo - How we want the vectors to look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the instanced wide vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the instance once created.

        Add a single screen marker. See addScreenMarkers() for details.

      • addScreenMarkers

        public ComponentObject addScreenMarkers(java.util.List<ScreenMarker> markers,
                                        MarkerInfo markerInfo,
                                        MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add screen markers to the visual display. Screen markers are 2D markers that sit on top of the screen display, rather than interacting with the geometry. Their visual look is defined by the MarkerInfo class.
        Parameters:
        markers - The markers to add to the display
        markerInfo - How the markers should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        This represents the screen markers for later modification or deletion.

                                 MarkerInfo markerInfo,
                                 MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add a single screen marker. See addMarkers() for details.

        markerInfo - How the markers should look.

      • addStickers

        public ComponentObject addStickers(java.util.List<Sticker> stickers,
                                   StickerInfo stickerInfo,
                                   MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add stickers on top of the globe or map. Stickers are 2D objects that drape over a defined area.
        Parameters:
        stickers - The list of stickers to apply.
        stickerInfo - Parameters that cover all the stickers in question.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        This represents the stickers for later modification or deletion.

        Returns:

      • addScreenLabels

        public ComponentObject addScreenLabels(java.util.List<ScreenLabel> labels,
                                       LabelInfo labelInfo,
                                       MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add screen labels to the display. Screen labels are 2D labels that float above the 3D geometry and stay fixed in size no matter how the user zoom in or out. Their visual appearance is controlled by the LabelInfo class.
        Parameters:
        labels - Labels to add to the display.
        labelInfo - The visual appearance of the labels.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        This represents the labels for modification or deletion.

      • addTexture

        public MaplyTexture addTexture(android.graphics.Bitmap image,
                               MaplyBaseController.TextureSettings settings,
                               MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add texture to the system with the given settings.
        Parameters:
        image - Image to add.
        settings - Settings to use.
        mode - Add on the current thread or elsewhere.

      • createTexture

        public MaplyTexture createTexture(int width,
                                  int height,
                                  MaplyBaseController.TextureSettings settings,
                                  MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Create an empty texture of the given size.
        Parameters:
        width - Width of the resulting texture
        height - Height of the resulting texture
        settings - Other texture related settings
        mode - Which thread to do the work on
        Returns:
        The new texture (or a reference to it, anyway)

      • addTexture

        public MaplyTexture addTexture(com.mousebird.maply.Texture rawTex,
                               MaplyBaseController.TextureSettings settings,
                               MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Add texture to the system with the given settings.
        Parameters:
        rawTex - Texture to add.
        settings - Settings to use.
        mode - Add on the current thread or elsewhere.

      • removeTexture

        public void removeTexture(MaplyTexture tex,
                          MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Remove a texture from the scene.
        Parameters:
        tex - Texture to remove.
        mode - Remove immediately (current thread) or elsewhere.

      • removeTextures

        public void removeTextures(java.util.List<MaplyTexture> texs,
                           MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Remove a whole group of textures from the scene.
        Parameters:
        texs - Textures to remove.
        mode - Remove immediately (current thread) or elsewhere.

      • addRenderTarget

        public void addRenderTarget(RenderTarget renderTarget)
        Add a render target to the system
        Sets up a render target and will start rendering to it on the next frame. Keep the render target around so you can remove it later.

      • removeRenderTarget

        public void removeRenderTarget(RenderTarget renderTarget)
        Remove the given render target from the system.
        Ask the system to stop drawing to the given render target. It will do this on the next frame.

      • addShaderProgram

        public void addShaderProgram(Shader shader,
                             java.lang.String sceneName)
        Associate a shader with the given scene name. These names let us override existing shaders, as well as adding our own.
        Parameters:
        shader - The shader to add.
        sceneName - The scene name to associate it with.

      • addActiveObject

        public void addActiveObject(ActiveObject activeObject)
        Add an active object that will be called right before the render (on the render thread).

      • removeActiveObject

        public void removeActiveObject(ActiveObject activeObject)
        Remove an active object added earlier.

      • disableObjects

        public void disableObjects(java.util.List<ComponentObject> compObjs,
                           MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Disable the given objects. These were the objects returned by the various add calls. Once called, the objects will be invisible, but can be made visible once again with enableObjects()
        Parameters:
        compObjs - Objects to disable in the display.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • disableObject

        public void disableObject(ComponentObject compObj,
                          MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Disable the display for the given object.
        Parameters:
        compObj - Object to disable
        mode - Where to execute the enable. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • enableObjects

        public void enableObjects(java.util.List<ComponentObject> compObjs,
                          MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Enable the display for the given objects. These objects were returned by the various add calls. To disable the display, call disableObjects().
        Parameters:
        compObjs - Objects to enable disable.
        mode - Where to execute the enable. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • enableObject

        public void enableObject(ComponentObject compObj,
                         MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Enable the display for the given object.
        Parameters:
        compObj - Object to enable.
        mode - Where to execute the enable. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • removeObject

        public void removeObject(ComponentObject compObj,
                         MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Remove a single objects from the display. See removeObjects() for details.

      • removeObjects

        public void removeObjects(java.util.List<ComponentObject> compObjs,
                          MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Remove the given component objects from the display. This will permanently remove them from Maply. The component objects were returned from the various add calls.
        Parameters:
        compObjs - Component Objects to remove.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addParticleSystem

        public ComponentObject addParticleSystem(ParticleSystem particleSystem,
                                         MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        This adds a particle system to the scene, but does not kick off any particles.
        Parameters:
        particleSystem - The particle system to start.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addParticleBatch

        public void addParticleBatch(ParticleBatch particleBatch,
                             MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Particles are short term objects, typically very small. We create them in large groups for efficience. You'll need to fill out the MaplyParticleSystem initially and then the MaplyParticleBatch to create them.
        Parameters:
        particleBatch - The batch of particles to add to an active particle system.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addClusterGenerator

        public void addClusterGenerator(ClusterGenerator generator)
        When the layout system clusters a bunch of markers or labels together, it needs new images to represent the cluster. You can provide a custom image for each group of markers by filling in one of these generates and passing it in.

      • addShapes

        public ComponentObject addShapes(java.util.List<Shape> shapes,
                                 ShapeInfo shapeInfo,
                                 MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        This method will add the given MaplyShape derived objects to the current scene. It will use the parameters in the description dictionary and it will do it on the thread specified.
        Parameters:
        shapes - An array of Shape derived objects
        shapeInfo - Info controlling how the shapes look
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addPoints

        public ComponentObject addPoints(java.util.List<Points> inPoints,
                                 GeometryInfo geomInfo,
                                 MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode mode)
        Adds a group of points all at once. We're assuming you want to draw a lot of points, so you have to group them together into a MaplyPoints.
        Parameters:
        inPoints - The points to add to the scene
        geomInfo - Controls how the points look
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addLight

        public void addLight(Light light)
        Add the given light to the list of active lights.
        This method will add the given light to our active lights. Most shaders will recognize these lights and do the calculations. If you have a custom shader in place, it may or may not use these. Triangle shaders use the lights, but line shaders do not.
        Parameters:
        light - Light to add.

      • removeLight

        public void removeLight(Light light)
        Remove the given light (assuming it's active) from the list of lights.
        Parameters:
        light - Light to remove.

      • clearLights

        public void clearLights()
        Clear all the currently active lights.
        There are a default set of lights, so you'll want to do this before adding your own.

      • resetLights

        public void resetLights()
        Reset the lighting back to its default state at startup.
        This clears out all the lights and adds in the default starting light source.

      • addBillboards

        public ComponentObject addBillboards(java.util.List<Billboard> bills,
                                     BillboardInfo info,
                                     MaplyBaseController.ThreadMode threadMode)

      • getMaxLineWidth

        public float getMaxLineWidth()
        Returns the maximum line width on the current device.
